The older version is optimised for hackintosh installation, so I suggest you use this one instead.  The SHA-1 checksum for the file "InstallESD.dmg" which is found inside "Install Mac OS X Lion.app" is: e05c4c7c43b210d0b8fc265c609f4dd70617ff86

Note this is not a bootable version.

It is bootable actually.  Just right click on the "Install Mac OS X.app", click "Show Package Content", then go to: Contents > SharedSupport, where you will find the image file: "InstallEST.dmg".  Burn it onto a DVD or a USB-stick and boot from there.
This torrent did not work for me. My current os is mac os 10.8. I burned this to dvd and did not work.

Got it working by doing this...

1. After you download, a file will appear "Install Mac OS X Lion".
2. Right click the file, and click on "Show Contents".
3. Go inside the "Contents" folder, and then "SharedSupport".
4. Double click "InstallESD.dmg".
5. It will verify for a minute or two, and then the actual installation file "Install Mac OS X Lion" will appear in a new window. Double click that file and follow the instructions.

Can anyone help me with this?

On your Leopard-equipped Mac, navigate to /System/Library/CoreServices.

Using a text editor that lets you enter an admin-user name and password to edit system-level filesâ€”such as the non-Mac App Store version of TextWranglerâ€”open SystemVersion.plist.

Locate the ProductVersion key (not the ProductUserVisibleVersion key). Just below that is a string of numbers indicating the OS version; for example, on a Mac running OS X 10.5.8, it will read 10.5.8.

Change that number to 10.6.6 (or 10.6.7 or 10.6.8), save the file (providing your admin-level username and password when prompted), and then shut down your Mac.

@Apokarteron: Could you please give me some suggestion.
Do i need to take backup and format before installing Lion over Leopard? Or can i just go forward download the dmg, do some internal changes as mentioned on other threads and run it so it ll get upgraded by itself.

OSX LION was built to be installed as an upgrade to Snow Leopard. You should back up your files (just in case) and then run the upgrade from your desktop. It takes about 30-45 mins to complete and all your settings and files should still be there. Some programs may not work properly, so just update them and chances are theres an update to make it compatible with lion. You shouldnt have a problem with ur mac if you install lion this way... 

If you run a clean install, you're going to have to take the dmg file found inside the .app and burn that to a CD and then install lion that way.
